title: H.P. Lovecraft
data:
[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[H. P. Lovecraft](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._P._Lovecraft "wikipedia:H. P. Lovecraft")***

**Howard Phillips Lovecraft** (August 20, 1890 – March 15, 1937) was an American writer of weird, science, fantasy, and horror fiction born in Providence, Rhode Island. He is best known for his creation of the **Cthulhu Mythos** and the fantasy and science fiction elements that it incorporated, which in turn led to the codification of the cosmic horror genre.

Lovecraft began writing speculative fiction in pulp magazines in 1913, and would start writing stories for what became known as the Cthulhu Mythos as early as 1920, beginning with "The Call of Cthulhu" - much of his work was published in Weird Tales, and though he was virtually unknown and unable to support himself from his literary work during his lifetime, he is now regarded as one of the most significant 20th-century authors of supernatural horror fiction. This is owed to a scholarly revival of Lovecraft's work in the 1970s that led to more widespread discovery of his work, as well as heavy criticism of his political views, particularly those he held until the post-Great Depression era of his life.

Lovecraft's works, their many direct adaptations and spiritual successors and the later contributions of other authors formed the Cthulhu Mythos as it is currently known: major themes include fear of the unknown, the nature of knowledge, and the idea that humanity is a fragile part of cosmic existence that could be swept away at any moment. The word "Lovecraftian" has since come to describe any being, location or thing that is considered sufficiently alien and unknowable in nature.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Influence on NetHack](#Influence_on_NetHack)

- [2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)

  - [2.1 Roles](#Roles)
  - [2.2 Deities](#Deities)
  - [2.3 Monsters](#Monsters)
  - [2.4 Items](#Items)
  - [2.5 Locations](#Locations)

- [3 Other variants and patches](#Other_variants_and_patches)

  - [3.1 Lethe patch](#Lethe_patch)
  - [3.2 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [3.3 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)

## Influence on NetHack

While vanilla *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* has not actively drawn from any of Lovecraft's works and/or the Cthulhu Mythos, several NetHack [variants](/wiki/Variant "Variant") and [patches](/wiki/Patch "Patch") contain monsters and themes derived from them: [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") has [Cthulhu](/wiki/Cthulhu "Cthulhu") and several other creatures of Lovecraftian origin among the various new monsters added; [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") has arguably the most direct Lovecraftian influence present in its themes and design, as well as its monster lineup, and this also extends to [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"). The [mind flayer](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer") as it appears in *NetHack* is not directly inspired by Lovecraft or the Mythos, but is commonly depicted as a humanoid similar to Cthulhu in appearance - the mind flayers' roles in other works and media also play on the themes of cosmic horror.

Below is a list of various features in variants of *NetHack* that are inspired in part or in whole by Lovecraft and the Cthulhu Mythos.

## dNetHack

dNetHack explicitly bills itself as "featuring horror elements reminiscent of those found in *Call of Cthulhu*" - both the original story and the tabletop game of the same name - and also incorporates many other elements from Lovecraft-influenced games and works, as well as mechanics that measure the player character's mental well-being and their ability to see "beyond the veil". dNetHack also portrays mind flayers and the deep ones as "r'lyehian", derived from the name of the sunken city [R'lyeh](/index.php?title=R%27lyeh\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "R'lyeh (page does not exist)") that appears in "The Call of Cthulhu".

For details on [sanity](/wiki/Sanity "Sanity") and [insight](/wiki/Insight "Insight"), visit the linked articles - **both of them contain major spoilers for dNetHack.** Below is a non-exhaustive list of dNetHack features inspired by the works of Lovecraft and the Cthulhu Mythos.

### Roles

- [Madperson](/wiki/Madperson "Madperson")

### Deities

- [Lobon](/index.php?title=Lobon\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Lobon (page does not exist)")
- [Tamash](/index.php?title=Tamash\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Tamash (page does not exist)")
- [Zo-Kalar](/index.php?title=Zo-Kalar\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Zo-Kalar (page does not exist)")
- [Bokrug](/index.php?title=Bokrug\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Bokrug (page does not exist)")
- [The Black Mother](/wiki/The_Black_Mother "The Black Mother")
- [Yog-Sothoth](/index.php?title=Yog-Sothoth\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Yog-Sothoth (page does not exist)")
- [Nyarlathotep](/index.php?title=Nyarlathotep\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Nyarlathotep (page does not exist)")

### Monsters

- b [shoggoth](/wiki/Shoggoth_\(dNetHack\) "Shoggoth (dNetHack)")

- B [byakhee](/wiki/Byakhee "Byakhee")

- Y [gug](/wiki/Gug "Gug")

- [migo](/wiki/Migo "Migo"):

  - F [migo worker](/wiki/Migo_worker "Migo worker")
  - F [migo soldier](/wiki/Migo_soldier "Migo soldier")
  - F [migo philosopher](/wiki/Migo_philosopher "Migo philosopher")
  - F [migo queen](/wiki/Migo_queen "Migo queen")

- g [nightgaunt](/wiki/Nightgaunt_\(dNetHack\) "Nightgaunt (dNetHack)")

- h [deep one](/wiki/Deep_one "Deep one")

  - h [deeper one](/wiki/Deeper_one "Deeper one")
  - H [deepest one](/wiki/Deepest_one "Deepest one")

- h [mind flayer](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer")
  - h [star spawn](/wiki/Star_spawn "Star spawn")

- & [Great Cthulhu](/wiki/Great_Cthulhu "Great Cthulhu")

- [Monster templates](/wiki/Monster_template "Monster template")
  - [yith](/index.php?title=Yith\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Yith (page does not exist)")

### Items

- R'lyehian faceplate

- [potion of space mead](/index.php?title=Potion_of_space_mead\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Potion of space mead (page does not exist)")

- Artifacts

  - [The Hand-Mirror of Cthylla](/index.php?title=The_Hand-Mirror_of_Cthylla\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "The Hand-Mirror of Cthylla (page does not exist)")
  - The [Necronomicon](/index.php?title=Necronomicon\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Necronomicon (page does not exist)")
  - [Nodensfork](/index.php?title=Nodensfork\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Nodensfork (page does not exist)")
  - [The Silver Key](/wiki/The_Silver_Key "The Silver Key")

### Locations

- [Neutral Quest](/wiki/Neutral_Quest "Neutral Quest")
  - Drowned City of R'lyeh

## Other variants and patches

### Lethe patch

- [Gehennom (Lethe patch)](/wiki/Gehennom_\(Lethe_patch\) "Gehennom (Lethe patch)")
  - Cthulhu's Sanctum

### [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM")

- [Migo](/wiki/Migo "Migo"):

  - a [migo drone](/wiki/Migo_drone "Migo drone")
  - a [migo warrior](/wiki/Migo_warrior "Migo warrior")
  - a [migo queen](/wiki/Migo_queen "Migo queen")

- B [byakhee](/wiki/Byakhee "Byakhee")

- B [nightgaunt](/wiki/Nightgaunt_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Nightgaunt (SLASH'EM)")

- h [deep one](/wiki/Deep_one "Deep one")

  - h [deeper one](/wiki/Deeper_one "Deeper one")
  - h [deepest one](/wiki/Deepest_one "Deepest one")

- P [shoggoth](/wiki/Shoggoth_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Shoggoth (SLASH'EM)")
  - P [giant shoggoth](/wiki/Giant_shoggoth "Giant shoggoth")

- V [star vampire](/wiki/Star_vampire "Star vampire")

- V [fire vampire](/wiki/Fire_vampire "Fire vampire")

- Z [gug](/wiki/Gug "Gug")

- h / & [Cthulhu](/wiki/Cthulhu "Cthulhu")

### [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack")

- h / & [Cthulhu](/wiki/Cthulhu "Cthulhu")

H.P. Lovecraft

From NetHackWiki

H. P. Lovecraft

Howard Phillips Lovecraft (August 20, 1890 – March 15, 1937) was an American writer of weird, science, fantasy, and horror fiction born in Providence, Rhode Island. He is best known for his creation of the Cthulhu Mythos and the fantasy and science fiction elements that it incorporated, which in turn led to the codification of the cosmic horror genre.

dNetHack explicitly bills itself as "featuring horror elements reminiscent of those found in Call of Cthulhu" - both the original story and the tabletop game of the same name - and also incorporates many other elements from Lovecraft-influenced games and works, as well as mechanics that measure the player character's mental well-being and their ability to see "beyond the veil". dNetHack also portrays mind flayers and the deep ones as "r'lyehian", derived from the name of the sunken city R'lyeh that appears in "The Call of Cthulhu".
